messageByLocale.en: You just finished the first part of the fling game tutorial.
Let's create a new project for this tutorial!
Set this to **no changes to the game size**.
First, let's find a border for our ring.
Let's choose an object from the asset store
We're looking for a tiled sprite that we can resize easily
Add this asset to your project.
Let's add the $(border) to our game!
Drag $(border) from the menu to the canvas.
Place and resize at least 4 instances of $(border) to create a closed frame around your screen ($(instancesCount:border)/4).
Now let's find an object that we can throw.
Let's choose an object from the asset store.
Select a circular sprite object that you'd like to throw (try **ball**).
Perfect, let's see how to throw it easily.
Add 3 instances of $(projectile) inside the frame.
Now let's find a target to aim.
Let's choose an object from the asset store.
Select an object that you would like to use as a target to throw $(projectile) at.
Perfect, let's add it to the scene.
Finally let's find something to protect $(target).
Let's choose an object from the asset store.
Select a **block** object you would like to use as an obstacle for your $(projectile).
Perfect, let's add it to the scene.
Let's add some sense of physics now.
Right click on $(border) and select “Edit behaviors”.
See the behaviors of the object here.
We'll see later how to use the other parameters. We're good now.
Now right click on $(projectile) and select “Edit behaviors”.
See the behaviors of the object here.
Now right click on $(target) and select “Edit behaviors”.
See the behaviors of the object here.
Now right click on $(block) and select “Edit behaviors”.
See the behaviors of the object here.
Now we'll make it possible to drag the $(projectile).

For this, we will install an **extension**.

Open the **Project Manager**
Search for the **draggable** extension (for physics objects).
Now right click on $(projectile) and select “Edit behaviors”.
See the behaviors of the object here.
Click on the **Preview** button to see how you can click and drag your $(projectile) around the scene!
You just finished the first part of the fling game tutorial.
We built together the foundations for a fling game.
Start the next part to improve your game visually.
Let's find a background for our game.
Let's choose an object from the asset store.
Perfect, let's use it in our scene.
Drag $(background) from the menu to the canvas.
Drag to expand the size of $(background) until it stretches over your entire game area.
Make sure that $(background) is selected and change this value to **-1**.
Let's choose an object from the asset store.
Perfect, let's add them to the scene.
Let's make them static so that they act as a wall.
Right click on $(obstacle) and select “Edit behaviors”.
See the behaviors of the object here.
Add a few $(obstacle) to the scene to protect $(target).
Now let's create a winning message!
This time, we'll create a text from scratch.
Drag $(youWinText) into the scene, and center it as well as possible.

Now select the $(youWinText) instance on the scene and change its layer using the properties panel.

It should have disappeared!
We are now going to add some logic to our game.
Alright, the condition is all set.
We will make $(target) disappear on collision.
Alright, $(target) will now disappear when $(projectile) hits it.
Let's add another action that will be executed for the same condition.
Alright, now the title should appear when the player hits $(target) with $(projectile).
Let's get back to the scene to create some constraints for the player.
We'll define an area where the player can grab $(projectile). Outside of this area, the $(projectile)s will be free.
Let's choose an object from the asset store
Drag $(grabArea) from the menu to the canvas.
Drag and resize $(grabArea) until it covers the lower left side of the game screen.
Make sure that $(background) is selected and change this value to **0**.
Let's deactivate the draggable behavior when outside of the $(grabArea).
Alright, the condition is all set.
Right click on this newly created condition and select “Invert condition”.
Select the action that releases the $(projectile) from the player drag.
Let's get back to the scene to place the $(projectile)s correctly.
Drag all instances of $(projectile) within the boundaries of $(background).
Arrange both $(block) and $(obstacle) in a way to protect $(target).
**Preview** the game and make sure it's winnable.
Once you're ready, we'll generate a link to share it.
First, you need to create an account.
Fill in the form and then click here.
After filling your info, click here.
Click here to publish your game.

Click here to open your game in your browser. Remember to share the link so that others can play your game!

Once you're done, close this dialog.
You just finished the second part of the fling game tutorial.
We improved your game visually and even published it so that anyone can play with it!
Start the next part that will show you how to have your players compare themselves thanks to leaderboards.
Right click on your $(background), and click “set as global object”.
Now let's create a new scene for our start screen.

Right click on the new scene and change its name to “StartScreen”.

Once you're done, click on the item to open the new scene.
Drag to expand the size $(background) until it stretches over your entire game area.
This time, we'll create a text from scratch.
Change the initial text to display whatever you want the title of your game to be.
Drag $(title) into the scene where you'd like your title to be.
Change the initial text to “Start Game”.
Drag $(startText) into the scene where you'd like the start button to be.
Now let's interact with those titles.
Alright, the condition is all set.
Alright, the condition is all set.
Alright, the action is all set.
Let's get back to the scene to add a score.
Let's create a text that will display the player score.
Let's create a text from scratch.
Change the initial text to display “Milliseconds: 0”.
Drag $(scoreText) into the top left corner of the screen.
We will create a timer that will start when the scene starts.
Select the **At the beginning of the scene** condition.
Select the **Start (or reset) a scene timer** action.
Copy this line and paste it here: `"Milliseconds: " + ToString(round(10*(TimerElapsedTime("Score"))))`.
Now we will display the other players scores.
In the event where $(target) gets deleted, click on “Add action”.
Select the option **Select the leaderboard from a list**.
Now the leaderboard should be displayed when $(projectile) reaches $(target).
Now we will ask the player to authenticate at game opening.
Select the **At the beginning of the scene** condition.
Alright, now players will be asked to login.
Now let's create a new scene that will be used to display the leaderboard.

Right click on the new scene and change its name to “Leaderboard”.

Once you're done, click on the item to open the new scene.
Let's add an event that makes sure the player comes back to the start screen after closing the leaderboard.
Select the **Leaderboard display has loaded** condition.
Right-click on the condition and select **Invert Condition**.
Let's add the action to come back to the start screen.
Alright, the action is all set.
Now let's save the score of the player.
In the event where $(target) gets deleted, click on “Add action”.

Let's change the scene to the leaderboard one (so that the play scene is closed).

In the event where $(target) gets deleted, click on “Add action”.
Alright, the action is all set.
Right-click on the start scene and select **Set as start scene**.
